description.plain:
Despite losing his sight at a young age, Stevie Wonder went on to become one of the most celebrated soul songwriters of the late 20th century. His songs manage to both innovate and catch the ears of listeners of all dispositions, whilst also being big chart hits.

Incredibly influential amongst musical circles, his voice rendered modern British soul-songwriter James Morrison close to tears the first time he heard it.

songs.title: As

description.plain: Someone more interested in generating sales would have named this song “Always.”  But Stevie already mastered the charts, so he named this song “As”, after the first word in the lyrics.  And sure enough, it became his thirty-fourth single to crack the Top 40.

Do know what I say is true

As today, I know I'm living, but tomorrow

So make sure when you say you're in it, but not of it
You're not helping to make this earth a place sometimes called Hell
Change your words into truth and then change that truth into love

songs.full_title: Superstition by Stevie Wonder
songs.title: Superstition

description.plain:
“Superstition” was a pivotal shift not only in Stevie Wonder’s career, but also in popular black music. The song in some ways represents the end of the Civil Rights Movement and the “sound of integration” Motown was providing. As the Black Power Movement was gaining steam, soul and funk music was about to become the predominate form of black musical expression, and “Superstition” represents the beginning of that shift.

“Superstition” is Stevie Wonder’s lead single from his fifteenth album, Talking Book.

The song topped the Billboard Hot 100 and Billboard’s Hot Soul Singles chart in January of 1973, and was certified Gold in the UK.

description.plain: This song was written, produced, and performed by Stevie Wonder for Gene Wilder’s 1984 romantic-comedy, “The Woman in Red.” The song won both the Golden Globe and Academy Award for Best Original Song, as well as three Grammy nominations. The song peaked at number 1 on a number of international singles charts.

songs.lyrics:
No New Year's Day to celebrate
No chocolate covered candy hearts to give away
No first of Spring, no song to sing
In fact here's just another ordinary day
No April rain, no flowers bloom
No wedding Saturday, within the month of June
But what it is, is something true
Made up of these three words that I must say to you

I just called to say I love you
I just called to say how much I care
I just called to say I love you
And I mean it from the bottom of my heart

No summer's high
No warm July
No harvest moon to light one tender August night
No autumn breeze
No falling leaves
Not even time for birds to fly to southern skies
No Libra sun
No Halloween
No giving thanks to all the Christmas joy you bring
But what it is, though old so new
To fill your heart like no three words could ever do

I just called to say I love you
I just called to say how much I care
I just called to say I love you
And I mean it from the bottom of my heart
I just called to say I love you
I just called to say how much I care
I just called to say I love you
And I mean it from the bottom of my heart

Of my heart
Of my heart

songs.lyrics:
Looking back on when I was a little nappy-headed boy
Then my only worry was for Christmas, what would be my toy
Even though we sometimes would not get a thing
We were happy with the joy the day would bring
Sneaking out the back door to hang out with those hoodlum friends of mine
Greeted at the back door with, "Boy, thought I told you not to go outside"
Tryin' your best to bring the water to your eyes
Thinking it might stop her from whoopin' your behind

I wish those days could come back once more
Why did those days ever have to go?
I wish those days could come back once more
Why did those days ever have to go?
'Cause I love them so

Brother said he's telling 'bout you playin' doctor with that girl
Just don't tell and I'll give you anything you want in this whole wide world
Mama gives you money for Sunday school
You trade yours for candy after church is through
Smokin' cigarettes and writing something nasty on the wall (You nasty boy)
Teacher sends you to the principal's office down the hall
You grow up and learn that kind of thing ain't right
But while you were doing it, it sure felt outta sight

I wish those days could come back once more
Why did those days ever have to go?
I wish those days could come back once more
Why did those days ever have to go?

songs.title: Don’t You Worry ’Bout a Thing

description.plain:
Stevie takes the role of someone offering to protect a woman from all of the world’s harsh realities. This including any form of corruption.

Innervisions covers the vast problems with today’s society, and “Don’t You Worry ‘Bout A Thing” seems to be the one of the most positive uplifting tracks on the album. With its vibrant Spanish instrumentals and energetic vocals, it’s easy to see why. But as we dwell into the narrative we can see the ruptured world surrounding the optimistic Stevie.

songs.full_title: Higher Ground by Stevie Wonder
songs.title: Higher Ground

description.plain:
Despite some misconceptions, “Higher Ground” was released before Stevie Wonder’s near-fatal car accident. However, one could be forgiven for this mistake: in the song, Wonder  speaks of his gratitude for being given another shot at life.

Though raised a Christian, Wonder has spoken of the benefits of other religious practices as well (ie. transcendental meditation). Here his message is reminiscent of the Buddhist concepts of the Samsara (the endless cycle of errors around him), Karma (his desire to improve the world), and an eventual Nirvana (the highest of spiritual grounds).

songs.full_title: Living for the City by Stevie Wonder
songs.title: Living for the City

description.plain:
Wonder tells the life story of a black man living in Mississippi during the Civil Rights era.



The man has seen the hardships faced by his family, but doesn’t allow that to discourage him and his future, so aspires to leave his hometown for opportunity in the promised land of New York City.

As he becomes an adult, he moves away to New York, but just gets caught up in a different system of inequality that imprisons him and leaves him homeless, jobless, and sick. He is left disillusioned, cautioning the listener that the city is not all that it is promised to be.

songs.full_title: Happy Birthday by Stevie Wonder
songs.title: Happy Birthday

description.plain:
Today a staple at birthday parties, Stevie Wonder’s “Happy Birthday” originally served as an unofficial commercial to call up people to sign the petition for a Martin Luther King Jr. Day.

Stevie also wrote down a few things about Martin Luther King Jr. Day in his album sleeve:


It is believed that for a man to lay down his life for the love of others is the supreme sacrifice. Jesus Christ by his own example showed us that there is no greater love. For nearly two thousand years now we have been striving to have the strength to follow that example. Martin Luther King was a man who had that strength. He showed us, non-violently, a better way of life, a way of mutual respect, helping us to avoid much bitter confrontation and inevitable bloodshed. We still have a long road to travel until we reach the world that was his dream. We in the United States must not forget either his supreme sacrifice or that dream.

I and a growing number of people believe that it is time for our country to adopt legislation that will make January 15, Martin Luther King’s birthday, a national holiday, both in recognition of what he achieved and as a reminder of the distance which still has to be traveled.

Join me in the observance of January 15, 1981 as a national holiday.

Stevland Morris a/k/a Stevie Wonder


The day was eventually signed into federal law by Ronald Reagan in 1983 and, first introduced in 1986, is now celebrated annually on the third Monday in January.

songs.full_title: Master Blaster (Jammin') by Stevie Wonder
songs.title: Master Blaster (Jammin’)

description.plain:
The Reggae-inspired “Master Blaster (Jammin')” was the first single off Stevie Wonder’s 1980 album Hotter Than July. The song interpolates “Jamming” by Bob Marley and the Wailers, one of several tributes to Marley in the track.

It was an international smash hit, topping the charts in four countries and reaching the top five in several more including the US and the UK.

songs.full_title: Ribbon in the Sky by Stevie Wonder
songs.title: Ribbon in the Sky

description.plain:
Ribbon in the Sky was released as a surprise single for the promotion of Stevie Wonder’s greatest-hits compilation album Stevie Wonder’s Original Musiquarium I.

The song peaked at #54 on the Billboard Hot 100 and #10 on Billboard’s R&B Singles chart in 1982 and was nominated for a Grammy for Best Male R&B Vocal Performance.

songs.full_title: Overjoyed by Stevie Wonder
songs.title: Overjoyed

description.plain: “Overjoyed” is a single from Stevie Wonder’s 1985 hit album In Square Circle. The lyrics describe a man hoping to bring to reality a romance that he’s only dreamed of. The song was originally recorded for Wonder’s concept album Journey Through The Secret Life Of Plants. The song reached #8 on the Billboard R&B charts and #1 on the Billboard Adult Contemporary Charts.

songs.full_title: Part-Time Lover by Stevie Wonder
songs.title: Part-Time Lover

description.plain:
“Part-Time Lover” was released as the lead single from Stevie Wonder’s 1985 album In Square Circle. It tells a story of undercover lovers, who hide their infidelity from their partners, only to find out in the end that their partners have been cheating on them as well.

The song reached #1 on the Billboard Hot 100, R&B, Dance and Contemporary Adult charts in late 1985. The song’s simultaneous chart success made him the first artist to score a number-one hit on four different Billboard charts. The song also reached number three on the UK singles chart and received a Grammy Award nomination for Best Male Pop Vocal Performance in 1986.

songs.title_with_featured: Love's in Need of Love Today

description.plain:
The song is about love in modern times and how the word and its meaning seems to have faded. It pleads with people to give love and to stop the hate.

This is the opening track to one the world’s most critically acclaimed albums of all time, Songs in the Key of Life.

songs.full_title: For Once in My Life by Stevie Wonder
songs.title: For Once in My Life

description.plain:
“For Once in My Life” is a swing song written by Ron Miller and Orlando Murden for Motown Records' Stein & Van Stock publishing company, and first recorded in 1965. It was written and first recorded as a slow ballad. There are differing accounts of its earliest versions, although it seems that it was first recorded by Barbara McNair, but first released in 1966 by Jean DuShon. Other early versions of the ballad were issued by The Four Tops, The Temptations, Diana Ross and Tony Bennett, whose recording was the first to reach the pop charts.

The most familiar and successful version of “For Once in My Life” is an uptempo arrangement by Stevie Wonder, recorded in 1967. Wonder’s version, issued on Motown’s Tamla label, was a top-three hit in the United States and the United Kingdom in late 1968 and early 1969. Gladys Knight & the Pips also recorded a slow tempo version in 1973.

songs.full_title: Pastime Paradise by Stevie Wonder
songs.title: Pastime Paradise

description.plain: Steve Lodder writes that the song can be understood in two different ways. It compares and contrasts the difference between the negative attitude of someone who has a flawed past, and the positive outlook of someone who wishes for a perfect future in this life or the next. Or, the song may be understood as Wonder describing how me-first materialism and laziness cannot compare to a strong work ethic which brings the great reward of heaven.

description.plain:
“Lately” is the ninth track on Stevie’s album Hotter Than July. It is also one of Stevie’s most know hit songs. The song is a hit and was famously covered by the legendary R&B group Jodeci.

https://youtu.be/2Lv0ngZun3g?t=50

The song is about the wonders of a person feeling that your woman or man is cheating or seeing someone else.

Hear me out

Is a time when a country celebrates
But as your hand touches your heart
Remember we all played a part
In America to help that banner wave

First clock to be made
In America was created
By a Black man
Scout who used no chart
Helped lead Lewis and Clark
Was a red woman
Use of martial arts
In our country got its start
By a yellow man
And the leader with a pen
Signed his name to free all men
Was a white man

We pledge allegiance
All our lives
To the magic colors
Red, blue, and white
But we all must be given
The liberty that we defend
For with justice not for all men
History will repeat again
It's time we learned
This world was made for all men
World was made for all men

World was made for all men

God saved His world for all men
All peoples
All babies
All children
All colors
All races
This world's for you
And me
This world
My world
Your world
Everybody's world
This world
Their world
Our world
This world was made for all men

Who was the first man to set foot on the North Pole?
Matthew Henson, a Black man
Who was the first American to show the Pilgrims at Plymouth the secrets of survival in the new world?
Squanto, a red man
Who was the soldier of Company G who won high honors for his courage and heroism in World War I?
Sing Kee, a yellow man
Who is the leader of United Farm Workers and helped farm workers maintain dignity and respect?
César Chávez, a brown man
Who was the father of blood plasma and the director of the Red Cross blood bank?
Dr. Charles Drew, a Black man
Who was the great American heroine who aided the Lewis and Clark expedition?
Sacagawea, a red woman
Who was the famous educator and semanticist who made outstanding contributions to education in America?
Hayakawa, a yellow man
Who invented the world's first stop light and the gas mask?
Garrett Morgan, a black man
Who was the American surgeon who was one of the founders of neurosurgery?
Harvey Williams Cushing, a white man
Who was the man who helped design the nation's capitol, made the first clock to give time in America, and wrote the first almanac?
Benjamin Banneker, a Black man
Who was the legendary hero who helped establish the League of Iroquois?
Hiawatha, a red man
Who is the leader of the first microbiotic center in America?
Micho Kushi, a yellow man
Who was the founder of the city of Chicago in 1772?
Jean Baptiste, a Black man
Who was one of the organizers of the American Indian Movement?
Denis Banks, a red man
Who was the Jewish financier who raised funds to sponsor Christopher Columbus' voyage to America?
Lewis D. Santangel, a white man
Who was the woman who led countless slaves to freedom on the Underground Railroad?
Harriet Tubman, a Black woman

description.plain:
“You Are the Sunshine of My Life” is a single from Stevie Wonder’s album “Talking Book.” It was written and produced by Stevie.

The song topped the Billboard Hot 100 for a week in May of 1973. It also became Stevie’s first number-one hit on Billboard’s Easy Listening chart and won a Grammy Award for “Best Male Pop Vocal Performance.”

songs.full_title: They Won't Go When I Go by Stevie Wonder
songs.title: They Won’t Go When I Go
songs.title_with_featured: They Won't Go When I Go

description.plain:
“They Won’t Go When I Go” has taken on its own legend since its release in 1974. The song’s origins date back to a bloody 1973 car accident that left Wonder spiritually altered and in a coma. This track is his reflection on the incident and his commitment to righteousness – sometimes in spite of others.

The message behind “They Won’t Go” could be perceived as callous: Wonder basically brags that he will get to heaven before others, due to their wicked ways. However, one could make the argument that Stevie is merely doing God’s work, chastising the wicked and deceitful around him while uplifting the innocent.

Either way, the Chopin-inspired ballad makes for a thoughtful listen and should please anyone already familiar with the track via George Michael’s 1990 cover.

songs.full_title: Rocket Love by Stevie Wonder
songs.title: Rocket Love

description.plain:
On “Rocket Love”, Stevie reminisces about a relationship that has since turned sour.

While the woman Stevie describes was “sensitive and warm”, and metaphorically even taking Stevie “riding in [her] rocket”, she has since let go of him, at a point where things were starting to feel like “heaven”, leaving Stevie feeling like he had been dropped back into “this cold, cold world”.

As with several other Stevie songs, he does a good job of painting vivid pictures of a woman’s love and beauty, (e.g. Golden Lady ) as well as her heartbreaking coldness (e.g.
 Blame it on the Sun ). In this song, Stevie brilliantly puts both these themes together that appraises this past lover as well as it describes her coldness.

songs.full_title: I Was Made to Love Her by Stevie Wonder
songs.title: I Was Made to Love Her
songs.title_with_featured: I Was Made to Love Her

description.plain: “I Was Made to Love Her,” from the 1967 album of the same name, is a song written by Stevie Wonder, Sylvia Moy, Henry Cosby and his mother, Lula Mae Hardaway. It peaked at No. 2 on the Billboard Pop Singles chart in July, 1967. It was just shy of surpassing “Light My Fire” by The Doors. It did, however, spend four non-consecutive weeks at No. 1 on the Hot Rhythm & Blues Singles chart.

songs.full_title: Never Dreamed You'd Leave in Summer by Stevie Wonder
songs.title: Never Dreamed You’d Leave in Summer
songs.title_with_featured: Never Dreamed You'd Leave in Summer

description.plain:
No songwriter can write a more poetic love song than Stevie Wonder. However, in “Never Dreamed You’d Leave in Summer,” Stevie uses his composition skills to pen a beautifully heartbreaking song of lost love.

Wonder uses the changing of the seasons as a metaphor for the growth and eventual erosion of a relationship. Just as the warmer months of spring and summer are joyful, so is a budding relationship. Therefore, it comes as a great shock to the speaker that his love ended so soon. He feels dumbfounded, betrayed, and heartbroken.

The song has been used multiple times since its debut, including in a memorable montage with Janet Jackson in 1993’s Poetic Justice. And even more powerfully, Stevie chose to sing the song at Michael Jackson’s memorial service in 2009.

songs.full_title: That Girl by Stevie Wonder
songs.title: That Girl

description.plain: “That Girl” was the lead single from Stevie Wonder’s greatest-hits compilation album Stevie Wonder’s Original Musiquarium I. It peaked at #4 on the Billboard Hot 100 and topped Billboard’s R&B Singles chart for nine weeks in 1982. “That Girl” also found success in Belgium, New Zealand, The Netherlands and the UK.

songs.full_title: Too High by Stevie Wonder
songs.title: Too High

description.plain:
Stevie Wonder may be blind, but he reads the national landscape, particularly regarding black America, with penetrating insight on Innervisions, the peak of his 1972-73 run of albums–including Music of My Mind and Talking Book.

Fusing social realism with spiritual idealism, Wonder brings expressive color and irresistible funk to his synth-based keyboards on Too High (a cautionary anti-drug song).

songs.full_title: All In Love Is Fair by Stevie Wonder
songs.title: All In Love Is Fair

description.plain:
The 7th song off of Stevie Wonder’s classic album Innervisions, released in 1973.

Stevie is able to contain and display so many different aspects of love and the affects it has in life in a song with so few words.

Both the words and music are written by Stevie, he also played all the instruments in recording the song.

songs.full_title: Summer Soft by Stevie Wonder

description.plain: The song captures the fleeting feelings of love and excitement as embodied by the changing seasons of the year. The seasons come promising you excitement and joy, and just as you come to expect more from it, it has left with no note, and the next season is in.

songs.full_title: You and I (We Can Conquer the World) by Stevie Wonder
songs.title: You and I (We Can Conquer the World)
songs.title_with_featured: You and I (We Can Conquer the World)

description.plain: On track three of Talking Book, Wonder continues to excel in the art of composing immaculate ballads. He believes that destiny has brought him someone to love, and in whom he can find strength. Having read the title, no one should be shocked to learn this track was the wedding song of Michelle and Barack Obama. Continuing with this matrimonial theme, the song was performed at Thelma Evans' wedding in the fifth season of the TV show Good Times.

songs.full_title: If It's Magic by Stevie Wonder
songs.title: If It’s Magic

description.plain:
Though never mentioned explicitly, “If It’s Magic” is about love and its preciousness. And as the song warns, if we’re not careful, it will be short-lived.

The song is the 16th in Wonder’s epic Songs in the Key of Life and the second track on the second LP. In accordance with Wonder’s all-encompassing instrumentals throughout the album, the song makes lovely use of the harp, played by Dorothy Ashby, and Wonder’s signature harmonica.

songs.full_title: Another Star by Stevie Wonder
songs.title: Another Star

description.plain:
“Another Star” is a lengthy latin disco song about heartbreak and the difficulties of getting over a break-up. It is the final song of the main body of Songs in the Key of Life – the next four songs come from the companion EP A Something’s Extra, which are generally perceived as outtakes.

Released as a single in 1977, it reached #32 on the Billboard Hot 100.

The song is sung from the perspective of a man who found his true love, his “star”, and though she broke his heart and may find “another star” who shines brighter than him, he is sure his heart won’t be satisfied with anyone besides her.

songs.full_title: You Haven't Done Nothing by Stevie Wonder
songs.title: You Haven’t Done Nothing

description.plain:
You Haven’t Done Nothin' is a single from Stevie Wonder’s album Fulfillingness' First Finale.

It was aimed at then-president Richard Nixon (who resigned from his presidency two days after the single was released) and is considered one of Stevie’s most pointed political statements.

The Jackson 5 sang the words “Doo da wop!” repeatedly in the song as Stevie sung the words, “Jackson 5, sing along with me.”

The song topped the Billboard Hot 100 for a week in November of 1974 and topped Billboard’s R&B Singles chart for two weeks in September of 1974.

The song topped the Billboard Hot 100 for a week in November of 1974 and topped Billboard’s R&B Singles chart for two weeks in September of 1974.

The second song on the side four of the original LP, this songs comes after “Isn’t She Lovely?”, so perhaps is inspired in her baby.

The “you” in the song could be anyone who’s love has healed his life e.g. a lover, a close friend, a relative, God etc.

songs.full_title: Village Ghetto Land by Stevie Wonder
songs.title: Village Ghetto Land

description.plain:
The overall lyrical theme of “Village Ghetto Land” is the patronizing manner in which the wealthy choose to address socioeconomic disparity, if at all. Stevie explores this concept through a series of stark, horrifying images of American inner-city poverty. The lyrics are framed as if the narrator is giving a tour of his neighborhood to upper-class elites.

Stylistically, the song is actually a synthesizer solo with vocal accompaniment, but sounds like a string ensemble piece. Wonder uses the Yamaha GX-1, a revolutionary and experimental polyphonic synthesizer, to produce the song’s warm string harmonies. The synths evoke the impression of a lush and uplifting orchestra, producing a striking contrast with the lyrics. It’s also what makes the song sound so modern for its time: Songs in the Key of Life was released in 1976, when synthesizers were still somewhat novel.

songs.title: Ghetto Village

songs.lyrics:
Would you like to go with me
Down my dead end street?
Would you like to come with me
To Village Ghetto Land?
See the people lock their doors
While robbers laugh and steal
Beggars watch and eat their meals from garbage cans

Broken glass is everywhere
It's a bloody scene
Killing plagues the citizens
Unless they own police
Children play with rusted cars
Sores cover their hands
Politicians laugh and drink, drunk to all demands

Families buying dog food now
Starvation roams the street
Babies die before they're born
Infected by the grief
Now some folks say that we should be
Glad for what we have
Tell me, would you be happy in Village Ghetto Land?

Village Ghetto Land

description.plain:
The song was written & produced by Stevie himself.

In 1972, the song peaked at #33 on the Billboard Hot 100 and #13 on Billboard’s Black Singles chart (which is now called the Hot R&B\Hip-Hop Songs chart).

This song was also about his former wife, Syreeta Wright.

songs.full_title: These Three Words by Stevie Wonder
songs.title: These Three Words

description.plain:
This, the third song from 1991’s Jungle Fever, is one of Stevie’s lesser-known ballads. However, the ballad is undeniable in its beauty and tenderheartedness. Throughout the song, Wonder reminds us all to cherish those we hold dear and love them while we still can.

In the words of poet Philip Larkin, “Of each other, we should be kind/While there is still time.”

songs.full_title: Saturn by Stevie Wonder
songs.title: Saturn

description.plain:
This song is the first of the four songs not originally on the Songs In The Key Of Life album, but appearing on the smaller EP entitled A Something’s Extra that went with the special edition of the original LP.

The song’s title is most likely an Eponym for the Roman God Saturn who was the god of wealth, liberation, agriculture, and time.

body.plain:
This song is the first of the four songs not originally on the Songs In The Key Of Life album, but appearing on the smaller EP entitled A Something’s Extra that went with the special edition of the original LP.

songs.lyrics:
Packing my bags, going away
To a place where the air is clean
On Saturn
There's no sense to sit and watch people die
We don't fight our wars the way you do
We put back all the things we use
On Saturn
There's no sense to keep on doing such crimes

There's no principles in what you say
No direction in the things you do
For your world is soon to come to a close
Through the ages, all great men have taught
Truth and happiness just can't be bought or sold
Tell me, why are you people so cold?

I'm going back to Saturn where the rings all glow

songs.full_title: Jesus Children of America by Stevie Wonder
songs.title: Jesus Children of America

description.plain: As a pious man, Wonder uses many of songs to address the state of contemporary religion. In “Jesus Children of America,” Stevie offers both praise and criticism for organized religion. Verse by verse, he questions the veracity of many worshipers' prayers and rebukes those who do not practice what they literally preach. As with almost all songs from Innervisions, Wonder plays every instrument on this track.

songs.full_title: Boogie On Reggae Woman by Stevie Wonder
songs.title: Boogie On Reggae Woman

description.plain:
“Boogie On Reggae Woman” was a single from Stevie Wonder’s album Fulfillingness' First Finale.

The song peaked at #25 on the Billboard Hot 100 and topped Billboard’s R&B Singles chart for two weeks between 1974 and 1975.

Don’t be fooled by the title: “Boogie On Reggae Woman” doesn’t contain any reggae or boogie music; just R&B and funk music.

songs.full_title: If You Really Love Me by Stevie Wonder
songs.title: If You Really Love Me

description.plain:
“If You Really Love Me” is a song written by Stevie Wonder and Syreeta Wright. Wonder recorded the song and released his version as a single from his 1971 album Where I’m Coming From. The single peaked in the top 10 of the Billboard Hot 100 (number 8), Billboard′s R&B chart (number 4), and Billboard′s Easy Listening chart (number 10).

The song was one of the last to feature Motown’s background band The Funk Brothers. After its release, Wonder left the Hitsville USA studios to record in New York City, playing most of the instruments himself. Wonder played Moog bass synthesizer[citation needed], drums, and piano on “If You Really Love Me”, while Wright is featured in the background singing.

description.plain: This track was recently featured on the FX series Atlanta. Season 2 episode 6, entitled “Teddy Perkins,” sees Darius visit a character of the same name to purchase a piano, but instead hears of Teddy’s brother Bennie Hope, an acclaimed pianist with a disfiguring disease. There are multiple parallels and direct references to Stevie Wonder, and his success despite hardship. “Evil” plays in the final scene, after Darius’s visit ends in tragedy, a possible attempt at confronting the ills that plague Atlanta’s troubled characters.

songs.lyrics:
Evil, why have you engulfed so many hearts? Evil
Evil, why have you destroyed so many minds?
Leaving room for darkness, where lost dreams can hide
Evil, why do you infest our purest thoughts, with hatred?
Evil, why have you stolen so much love?
Leaving everyone's emotions lost and wandering free
Evil, why have you taken over God's children's eyes? Evil
Evil, before they could really grow to see
That your way, is not the way, to make, life what it should be
Evil, why have you destroyed, you've destroyed so much of this doggone world?
Evil, hey, evil, oh, why have you broken so many homes?
Leaving sweet love all alone, an outcast of the world

description.plain:
Wonder’s last Top 40, to date.

This song is the first single of the minor album by Stevie, Characters.

The song peaked at number 19 on the Billboard Hot 100.

The song regained popularity after being featured in the trailer of the blockbuster videogame Grand Theft Auto V.

songs.full_title: Send One Your Love by Stevie Wonder
songs.title: Send One Your Love

description.plain:
“Send One Your Love” was the lead single from Stevie Wonder’s Journey Through The Secret Life Of Plants, released in 1979. It peaked at #4 in the US the last week of the 1970s decade and stayed there for the first week of the 1980s. It also reached the top 10 in both Canada and Germany. “Send One Your Love” was the album’s only single to reach the top 40 in any country.

In 1998, the DC hip hop group Born Jamericans scored a minor hit when they heavily sampled this song in their track “Send My Love/Send One Your Love”.

songs.title: Can’t Put It in the Hands of Fate
songs.title_with_featured: Can’t Put It in the Hands of Fate (Ft. Busta Rhymes, CHIKA, Cordae & Rapsody)

description.plain:
Released in support of the 2020 George Floyd Protests, this song lambasts the slow progress of racial justice in the United States. Referencing the murders of George Floyd and Breonna Taylor, the artists highlight the 2020 protests' roots in previous protests such as NFL quarterback Colin Kaepernick kneeling in protest during the U.S. national anthem.

songs.full_title: You Will Know by Stevie Wonder
songs.title: You Will Know

description.plain:
You Will Know is the second single & opening track from Stevie Wonder’s 21st album Characters.

The song peaked at #77 on the Billboard Hot 100, topped Billboard’s R&B Singles chart for a week in March of 1988 (becoming Stevie’s eighteenth number-one R&B hit) and peaked at #16 on Billboard’s Adult Contemporary Tracks chart.

songs.full_title: Blame It on the Sun by Stevie Wonder
songs.title: Blame It on the Sun

description.plain:
“Blame it On the Sun”, like “All in Love is Fair” and many other beautiful ballads, is a painful, heartfelt lament for a love that is no more.

In this track off Stevie’s fifteenth album “Talking Book”, Stevie is seen questioning his ability to maintain his sanity after a sour relationship has left him heartbroken. We see Stevie blame it on nature, as if saying that the things happening to him are natural and the heartbreak was inevitable. But as the song progresses, we see Stevie realise that maybe it was his own fault that the relationship turned sour.

songs.full_title: All Day Sucker by Stevie Wonder
songs.title: All Day Sucker

description.plain:
This is the second to last song in Songs in the Key of Life.

It’s about a man who loves a woman but feels that it isn’t reciprocate, as the woman doesn’t “give any of the love”

The song also seems to delve into the matters of a one-sided relationship. The narrator obviously wants more from the relationship at hand, but at each turn his lover denies that advancement. This lover continuously asks for forgiveness and the chance to see the narrator again. Instead of learning from past experiences, the narrator continuously ends up in a never ending cycle of offering himself and getting nothing in return.

songs.full_title: Bird Of Beauty by Stevie Wonder
songs.title: Bird Of Beauty

description.plain:
This is the fourth track on Side Two of Stevie’s Fulfillingness' First Finale and it is well known for it’s fusion of Brazilian influence with Stevie’s Motown past (Deniece Williams sang backing vocals). The track makes use of the Cuíca and a faint Samba rhythm. The world-renowned Sergio Mendes lends a helping hand and penned the Portuguese lyrics.

Amongst the danceable and exotic rhythms, Wonder preaches mental liberation and encourages the listener to celebrate life as one might do the Carnaval.

songs.full_title: Never in Your Sun by Stevie Wonder
songs.title: Never in Your Sun

description.plain: On the fifth song of his 1985 album, Stevie Wonder spins a perplexing tale of meeting an enigmatic and enchanting woman. Though his lyrics are easy to follow, Wonder offers little clarity as to the song’s meaning. Regardless, the song delights thanks to its catchy melodies, snapping rhythm, and Stevie’s trademark musical ubiquity.

songs.full_title: I Ain't Gonna Stand for It by Stevie Wonder
songs.title: I Ain’t Gonna Stand for It
songs.title_with_featured: I Ain't Gonna Stand for It

description.plain: “I Ain’t Gonna Stand for It” is the second single from Stevie Wonder’s 1980 album, Hotter Than July. It reached number four on the Billboard R&B singles chart and number 11 on the Hot 100. It also hit number 10 on the UK Singles Chart. The song is famous for Wonder’s imitation of a seasoned country-and-western crooner and his inspiring drumming. Charlie and Ronnie Wilson of The Gap Band provide backing vocals on the song.

songs.title_with_featured: You Can't Judge a Book by Its Cover

description.plain: According to Nelson George’s 1986 book Where Did Our Love Go? The Rise and Fall of the Motown Sound, this was the song the Funk Brothers were recording when they learned of the passing of legendary Motown drummer Benny Benjamin. “Papa Zita”, renowned for his heavy and thunderous style on tracks such as the Temptations' Get Ready and Wonder’s own Uptight (Everything’s Alright), had been suffering from drug and alcohol addiction for several years, and ultimately died of a stroke on April 20, 1969, aged 43.

songs.full_title: I Don't Know Why by Stevie Wonder
songs.title: I Don’t Know Why

description.plain:
I Don’t Know Why was a song written by Stevie Wonder for his 1968 album titled For Once In My Life





The song is a magnificent work of Wonder that expresses the complexity of the relationship Wonder bellows about in the song.



The hit television show Scandal’s S2E4,Whiskey Tango Foxtrot, gives a perfect visual representation of the tension and frustration Wonder croons on this track of a dysfunctional relationship.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=NMS1nBKdKNg

songs.full_title: Lookin' for Another Pure Love by Stevie Wonder
songs.title: Lookin’ for Another Pure Love

description.plain: The song is about Stevie Wonder’s search for another love like he has experienced once before. He never felt heartbreak or sadness until this woman left him. While the song mainly mentions Wonder’s search for a love pure like he once had, it also addresses Wonder’s concern with his old partner, as well as simultaneously teaching them a lesson (specifically in verse 2).

body.plain: A song about a fictional account of a soldier in the Vietnam war; detailing their struggles, gripes, and aftermath of being in such a war

songs.lyrics:
I am a veteran of the war
I up and joined the army back in 1964
At sixteen I just had to be a man at any cost
I volunteered for Vietnam where I got my leg shot off

I recall a quote from a movie that said "Who's more a man
Than a man with a reason that's worth dying for"

They had me standing on the front line
They had me standing on the front line
They had me standing on the front line
But now I stand at the back of the line when it comes to getting ahead

They gave me a uniform and a tiny salty pill
To stop the big urge I might have for the wrong kind of thrill
They put a gun in my hand and said, "Shoot until he's dead
But it's hard to kill when 'please, I'm your friend' echoes through your head

Brought up in church taught no man should take another's life
But then put in a jungle where life has no price

They had me standing on the front line
They had me standing on the front line
They had me standing on the front line
But now I stand at the back of the line when it comes to getting ahead

Back in the world the paper reads today
Another war is in the brewing
But what about the lives of yesterday
And the many happy families that have been ruined

My niece is a hooker and my nephew's a junkie too
But they say I have no right to tell them how they should do
They laugh and say "Quit bragging" 'bout the war you should never have been in
But my mind is so brain-washed I'd probably go back and do it again

I walk the neighborhood parading my purple heart
With a fear of agent orange that no one will stop, no

They had me standing on the front line
They had me standing on the front line
They had me standing on the front line
But now I stand at the back of the line when it comes to getting ahead, yeah
They had me standing on the front line
They had me standing on the front line
They had me standing on the front line
Now I stand at the back of the line when it comes to getting ahead
Could you believe I do?
They had me standing on the front line
They had me standing on the front line
They had me standing on the front line
But now I stand at the back of the line when it comes to getting ahead

songs.full_title: I Love You Too Much by Stevie Wonder
songs.title: I Love You Too Much

description.plain:
The protagonist of this song is, at this juncture in his relationship with the object of his affection (to whom this song is directed), laying all his cards on the table and upping the ante…Put quite simply, Stevie is sprung.

Courtesy of The Eternal Sorrow @ urbandictionary.com, November 10, 2006:

sprung (/sprəNG/), v.

1) To fall deeply in love with one person, in a short period of time.

2) Willing to do anything to please someone you love. Rather it be embarassing yourself, or being extremely romantic.

3) The retarded ass mother fucker who sings that damn song “I’m sprung” is fucking sprung on saying sprung…

4) Refusing to live without that person by your side.

songs.full_title: Go Home by Stevie Wonder
songs.title: Go Home

description.plain:
Go Home was a single released from Stevie Wonder’s album In Square Circle.

The song peaked at #10 on the Billboard Hot 100, #2 on Billboard’s R&B Singles chart, topped Billboard’s Adult Contemporary for a week and topped Billboard’s Hot Dance Music\Club Play chart for two weeks in January of 1985.

songs.full_title: Girl Blue by Stevie Wonder
songs.title: Girl Blue

description.plain: One of the most slept on Stevie Wonder’s songs ever.  This beat just takes you away.  It’s so amazing how Stevie played every instrument on this song despite the state he is in.  This song is about a female being sad and having a cold heart, and the artist trying to encourage her to have a more-positive outlook on life.

songs.full_title: Purple Rain Drops by Stevie Wonder
songs.title: Purple Rain Drops

description.plain:
“Purple Rain Drops” is a blues ballad, recorded two years previously in 1963. It has been claimed that this song was the first musical reference to “purple rain,” long before Prince dropped his classic 1984 album, Purple Rain. As the B-side for “Uptight (Everything’s Alright)”—a #3 hit single—many consider it to be a strange inclusion.

The track itself is more or less a recycled version of “Tears In Vain,” released almost a full year prior. It also features one of very few contributions from songwriter Ted Hull in the Motown catalog. Both songs had the same producer, and it has been claimed in recent years that Hull got a “free ride” for his credit. If anything, the song marks a transition from “Little Stevie” to the budding creative force he was destined to become.

songs.full_title: Yester-Me, Yester-You, Yesterday by Stevie Wonder
songs.title: Yester-Me, Yester-You, Yesterday

description.plain:
Yester-Me, Yester-You, Yesterday was a single from Stevie Wonder’s album My Cherie Amour. The song was originally recorded by Chris Clark in 1966.

At the time of the single’s release, Stevie was going through some vocal issues and had to wait before recording a song. Because of this, Motown decided to release songs that Stevie recorded years earlier instead of making him record new songs.

Stevie recorded Yester-Me, Yester-You, Yesterday two years before the single’s release.

The song peaked at #7 on the Billboard Hot 100 and #5 on Billboard’s R&B Singles chart in 1969. It also managed to peak at #2 on the U.K. Singles chart.
